person.name: Wyatt Kirby
person.title: Founding Partner
person.bio:
An accidental developer, Wyatt came to software and small business by an
unconventional route. As a cofounder at Apsis, he has helped build a team of
exceptional engineers, one equipped to deliver effective solutions fast.
After more than a decade, Wyatt _keeps_ coming back to software because it
offers a rare convergence of interests: writing, teaching, and tech.
A graduate of Bennington College in Vermont, Wyatt's appreciation for clear
communication has come to define Apsis's engineering team: understanding first,
technology second. This focus leads to asking the right questions, finding the
right answers, and delivering success year after year.


After work, you'll find Wyatt enjoying time with his wife and daughter, playing
with the cat, roasting coffee, cooking dinner, or arguing on the internet about
college football.
person.bio_short:
An accidental developer turned entrepreneur, Wyatt has helped build a team of exceptional
engineers at Apsis. After a decade in the field, he continues to be drawn to software for
its blend of writing, teaching, and tech.

posts.author: wyatt
posts.title: One of our clients hasn't paid us $130k — or "Why Every Contract Clause Matters"
posts.excerpt: One of our clients hasn’t paid us. They haven’t paid us for 6 months. This is the brief story of lessons learned — or almost learned.
posts.desc: One of our clients hasn't paid us. They haven't paid us for 6 months. This is the brief story of lessons learned — or almost learned.

posts.author: wyatt
posts.title: Be easy to fire
posts.excerpt: At Apsis, we’re not afraid of being let go — in fact, we want it. Our goal is to help clients grow and succeed, and eventually move on. We operate on simple principles: transparency, simplicity, and clear communication. When it’s time to say goodbye, we’re here to make the handoff smooth and seamless.
posts.desc: At Apsis, we're not afraid of being let go — in fact, we want it. Our goal is to help clients grow and succeed, and eventually move on. We operate on simple principles: transparency, simplicity, and clear communication. When it's time to say goodbye, we're here to make the handoff smooth and seamless.

person.name: Chris Pfohl
person.title: Senior Engineer & Data Engineer
person.bio:
Chris is an expert data mover, munger, and analyzer. He builds robust third
party integrations, answers tough questions with data, and brings order to
databases and applications to empower new features and higher reliability.


Chris loves to share his expertise with newer developers through code
review, teaching, and good documentation. He also loves writing code that's
hard to use wrong and creating tools that empower his team to deliver faster
and more reliably. He was drawn to programming, and contract work in
particular because of his deep love of learning, solving problems, and
sharing that knowledge.
person.bio_short:
A master data mover and analyzer, Chris crafts robust integrations and sorts
through complexity with ease. He loves sharing his expertise through code review,
teaching, and rock-solid documentation.

posts.author: chris
posts.title: Save Time with Bash Programmable Autocompletion
posts.excerpt: What follows is a short tutorial on bash autocompletion and a tiny bit of bash programming information. It assumes you have a working knowledge of programming, and at least passing familiarity with your terminal.
posts.desc: What follows is a short tutorial on bash autocompletion and a tiny bit of bash programming information. It assumes you have a working knowledge of programming, and at least passing familiarity with your terminal.

posts.author: wyatt
posts.title: Thanks, ElectronConf
posts.excerpt:
Over the weekend, my usual sources for industry news exploded in response to the postponement of the first ElectronConf because the panel of speakers did not “reflect the standards to which we hold ourselves.”

First: thank you. Thank you to ElectronConf and to…
posts.desc:
Over the weekend, my usual sources for industry news exploded in response to [the postponement](http://electronconf.com/) of the first ElectronConf because the panel of speakers did not "reflect the standards to which we hold ourselves."

First: _thank you_. Thank you to ElectronConf and to…

person.name: Niall Wingham
person.title: Apsis Alum
person.bio:
Niall is a cheerful curmudgeon and likes reading language and
protocol specifications. He lives with his professorial wife
and pint-sized daughter in Toronto, and is by default the head
of the Canadian branch of Apsis. When he grows up he wants to
be a farmer, or maybe a ballet dancer, or no, wait, a sailor!
person.bio_short:

posts.author: niall
posts.title: Parsing JSON with Types (Part 1)
posts.excerpt: I like to have well-defined models of my application data, especially at service boundaries. I usually also define types in my application code to reflect these models. When data are sent from a service, their values are serialized and their types are mapped onto the type system of the…
